original: pañcamyantākṣaraśrutyā bhūtaprakṛteḥ pratyabhijñānātprathamāntaparaśabdoktasya jagannimitteśvarasya sarvajñatvādikamityāhaatrocyata iti /
analyzed: pañcamī anta akṣara śrutyā bhūta prakṛteḥ pratyabhijñānāt prathama anta para śabda uktasya jagat nimitta īśvarasya sarvajñatva ādikam iti āha atra ucyate iti
translated: Because the material cause of beings is recognized by the pronoun ending in the fifth case, the cause of the world spoken of by the pronoun ending in the first case is omniscience, etc. He says To this we reply, etc.

original: 'saṃdigdhe tu vākyaśeṣāt'iti nyāyena siddhāntayatievaṃ prāpta iti /
analyzed: saṃdigdhe tu vākyaśeṣāt iti nyāyena siddhāntayati evam prāptaḥ iti
translated: In the case of doubt, however, from the supplementary passage (Sūtra 1.3.8), he concludes the discussion with the words Thus it has been concluded.

original: cetanācetanatvena saṃdigdhe bhūtayonau 'yaḥ sarvajñaḥ'iti vākyaśeṣādīśvaratvanirṇaya ityayuktaṃ /
analyzed: cetana acetana tvena saṃdigdhe bhūtayonau yaḥ sarvajñaḥ iti vākya śeṣāt īśvara tva nirṇayaḥ iti ayuktam
translated: It is not proper to determine the Lord by the supplementary passage He who is omniscient (Śvet. 6.19), when there is doubt about the source of beings being conscious or non-conscious.

original: vākyaśeṣe bhūtayoneḥ pratyabhijñāpakābhāvāditi śaṅkatenanviti /🔽'janikartṛḥ prakṛtiḥ'iti sūtreṇa prakṛterapādānasaṃjñāyāṃ pañcamīsmaraṇādakṣarātsaṃbhavatīti
analyzed: vākya śeṣe bhūtayoneḥ pratyabhijñāpaka abhāvāt iti śaṅkate nanu iti  jani kartṛḥ prakṛtiḥ iti sūtreṇa prakṛteḥ apādāna saṃjñāyām pañcamī smaraṇāt akṣarāt saṃbhavati iti
translated: He raises the doubt with the words But, surely...

analyzed: prakṛti tvena uktā akṣarasya bhūtayoniḥ vākyaśeṣe tasmāt iti prakṛti tva liṅgena pratyabhijñānam asti iti
translated: By the aphorism The material cause is called the source (Panini 1.4.35), the fifth case is remembered for the material cause. Therefore, the source of beings, mentioned as the material cause by the word akṣara (imperishable), is recognized in the supplementary passage by the mark of being the material cause, with the words from that (Śvet. 6.13).

analyzed: samādhatte atra ucyate iti
translated: He answers with the words To this we reply...

analyzed: etat kāryam brahma sūkṣma ātmakam nāma rūpam
translated: This effect of Brahman is subtle, consisting of name and form.

analyzed: sthūlam tatas nnam vrīhi ādi iti arthaḥ
translated: The gross is food, such as rice, etc. This is the meaning.

analyzed: yat uktam pañcamī anta akṣara śrutyā bhūtayoneḥ pratyabhijñāna da cetana tvam iti
translated: It has been said that the source of beings is recognized by the mention of the word akṣara (imperishable) ending in the fifth case, and so it is non-conscious.

analyzed: tatra āha akṣarāt paratas iti
translated: To that he says Beyond the akṣara...

analyzed: na ayam akṣara śabdaḥ bhūtayonim parāmṛśati
translated: This word akṣara does not refer to the source of beings.

original: paravidyādhigamyatvenoktasyākṣarasya bhūtayoneḥ 'akṣaraṃ puruṣaṃ vedā'ityakṣaraśrutyā vedyatvaliṅgavatyā pūrvameva brahmatvena parāmarśādityāhayeneti
analyzed: para vidyā adhigamya tvena uktasya akṣarasya bhūtayoneḥ akṣaram puruṣam veda iti akṣara śrutyā vedya tva liṅgavatyā pūrvam eva brahmatvena parāmarśāt iti āha yena iti
translated: The Self is Brahman, because it is spoken of as the source of all beings, and because it is the object of the highest knowledge, and because it is referred to as Brahman in the passage, He who knows the Imperishable as the Person, &c, and because it is spoken of as the highest object of knowledge in the passage, He who is without breath, without mind, pure, &c, and because it is said to be higher than the Imperishable, and because it is said to be the highest source of all beings, therefore it is Brahman.

original: yena jñānenākṣaraṃ bhūtayoniṃ sarvajñaṃ puruṣaṃ veda tāṃ brahmavidyāṃ yogyāya śiṣyāya
analyzed: yena jñānena akṣaram bhūta yonim sarvajñam puruṣam veda tām brahma vidyām yogyāya śiṣyāya
translated: He who knows the Imperishable, the source of all beings, the allknowing Person, to him the teacher should impart that knowledge of Brahman to a fit pupil.

original: prabrūyādityupakramya 'aprāṇo hyamanāḥ śubhraḥ' 'akṣarātparataḥ paraḥ'ityucyamānaḥ🔽paro bhūtayoniriti gamyata ityarthaḥ /
analyzed: prabrūyāt iti upakramya aprāṇaḥ hi amanāḥ śubhraḥ akṣarāt paratas paraḥ iti ucyamānaḥ  paras bhūtayoniḥ iti gamyate iti arthaḥ
translated: Having thus begun, it is said that the Imperishable is without breath, without mind, pure, and that the highest source of all beings is higher than the Imperishable.🔽This is the meaning.

original: tarhi pañcamyantākṣaraśabdārthaḥ ka ityāśaṅkyājñānamiti vakṣyata ityāhakathamiti /
analyzed: tarhi pañcamī anta akṣara śabda arthaḥ kaḥ iti āśaṅkya ajñānam iti vakṣyate iti āha katham iti
translated: If so, what is the meaning of the word Imperishable in the locative case? Anticipating this question, he will say it is ignorance. He says how?

analyzed: para vidyā iti samākhyayā api tad viṣayasya brahma tvam iti āha api ca iti
translated: By the designation of the highest knowledge, the object of that knowledge is Brahman. He says moreover.

analyzed: nanu pradhāna vidyā api kāraṇa viṣaya tvāt parā iti atas āha para apara vibhāgaḥ iti
translated: But the knowledge of the pradhāna also is the knowledge of the cause, and hence is the highest. To this he says the distinction between the highest and the lowest.

original: anityaphalatvenāparavidyāṃ ninditvā muktyarthine brahmavidyāṃ provāceti vākyaśeṣokterityarthaḥ /
analyzed: anitya phalatvena apara vidyām ninditvā mukti arthine brahma vidyām provāca iti vākya śeṣa ukteḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: Having censured the knowledge of the pradhāna as having a perishable fruit, he taught the knowledge of Brahman to one who sought liberation. This is the meaning of the concluding statement.

analyzed: astu pradhānavidyā api mukti phalatvena parā iti atas āha na ca iti
translated: Let the principal knowledge also be the fruit of liberation. To this he says: Not so.

analyzed: nanu yaḥ sarvajñaḥ iti agre para vidyā viṣayaḥ ucyate
translated: But it is said that the omniscient one is mentioned later as the object of supreme knowledge.

analyzed: adreśya vākyena tu pradhāna vidyā ucyate iti atas āha tisraḥ ca iti
translated: But the principal knowledge is mentioned by the statement about the invisible. To this he says: And three.

analyzed: itas ca bhūtayoneḥ brahmatvam iti āha kasmin iti
translated: And for this reason also, the source of beings is Brahman. He says: In whom.

original: acetanamātrasyaikāyatanamupādānaṃ tajjñānātkāryajñāne 'pi tadakāryāṇāmātmanāṃ jñānaṃ na bhavati /
analyzed: acetana mātrasya eka āyatanam upādānam tad jñānāt kārya jñāne pi tat akāryāṇām ātmanām jñānam na bhavati
translated: The material cause is the abode of mere non-sentient matter. Even from the knowledge of that, there is no knowledge of the effects of that, of the selves which are not its effects.

original: evaṃ jīve jñāte tadakāryasya bhogyasya jñānaṃ na bhavatītyarthaḥ /
analyzed: evam jīve jñāte tat akāryasya bhogyasya jñānam na bhavati iti arthaḥ
translated: Similarly, when the individual soul is known, there is no knowledge of the enjoyer which is not its effect. This is the meaning.

analyzed: brahmavidyā śabdāt ca bhūtayoniḥ brahma iti āha api ca iti
translated: And from the word Brahman-knowledge, the source of beings is Brahman. He says: Moreover.

original: sa brahmavidyāṃ sarvavidyānāṃ pratiṣṭhāṃ samāptibhūmiṃ brahmavidyāmuvāca /
analyzed: sa brahma vidyām sarva vidyānām pratiṣṭhām samāpti bhūmim brahma vidyām uvāca
translated: He spoke of Brahman-knowledge, the foundation of all knowledge, the ground of completion, of Brahman-knowledge.

analyzed: brahmaṇi sarva vidyānām vidyā phalānām ca antarbhāvāt brahmavidyā sarva vidyā pratiṣṭhā
translated: Because Brahman includes all knowledge and the fruits of knowledge, Brahman-knowledge is the foundation of all knowledge.

analyzed: nanu apara vidyā para prakaraṇe kimartham uktā iti atas āha aparā iti

analyzed: yajate iti yajamānaḥ

analyzed: etat eva karma śreyaḥ na anyat ātma jñānam iti ye mūḍhāḥ tuṣyanti te punar punarjanma maraṇam āpnuvanti iti arthaḥ

analyzed: nahi mūlaprakṛteḥ bhede kiñcid mānam asti

analyzed: na ca indraḥ māyābhiḥ iti śrutiḥ mānam

translated: Because, by the power of many Upanishad statements such as The unborn One alone, aided by the reasoning of simplicity, that statement [of Indra with his illusions] is an explanation of the difference of illusions by the difference of cognitions.

analyzed: tat uktam sureśvara ācāryaiḥ svatas tu avidyā bhedaḥ manāk api na vidyate iti

analyzed: anyathā iti uktam sphuṭayati tat ced iti

original: svarūpaṃ cejjñānina eva vyañjyeta jñānātpūrvaṃ vyavahārocchittirityarthaḥ /
analyzed: sva rūpam ced jñāninaḥ eva vyañjyeta jñānāt pūrvam vyavahāra ucchittiḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: If the nature [of the soul] were manifested only in the knower, there would be cessation of worldly activity before knowledge. This is the meaning.

analyzed: atas sadā eva vyakta svarūpa tvāt iti arthaḥ
translated: Therefore, the meaning is: because it is always of the nature of manifestation.

original: sadā vṛttiṣu vyaktasya vastuto 'saṅgasyātmana āvidyakadehādyavivekarūpasya malasaṅgasya sattvāttadvivekāpekṣayā samutthānādiśrutirityuttaramāhaatreti
analyzed: sadā vṛttiṣu vyaktasya saṅgasya ātmanaḥ āvidyaka deha ādi aviveka rūpasya mala saṅgasya sattvāt tad viveka apekṣayā samutthāna ādi śrutiḥ iti uttaram āha atra iti
translated: The answer is: Here, the statement about arising, etc. is in relation to the distinction of that, because the Self, which is actually unattached and manifest in the modifications, has the impurity of the form of non-discrimination from the body, etc. that are superimposed due to ignorance, and because of the need for the distinction of that.

analyzed: vedanā harṣa śoka ādiḥ
translated: Feeling is joy, sorrow, etc.

analyzed: aviviktam iva iti tādātmyasya saṅgasya kalpita tvam uktam
translated: It is said that the superimposition of identity, which is the form of attachment, is imagined, by the phrase as if undifferentiated.

analyzed: tatra kalpita saṅge dṛṣṭāntaḥ yathā iti  śruti kṛtam iti
translated: The example for the imagined attachment there is stated by the word 'yathā' (as).

analyzed: tvam padārtha śrutyā yaḥ yam vijñāna mayaḥ prāṇeṣu ityādyayā siddham iti arthaḥ
translated: 'By the Vedic text' means that it is established by the passage 'This one consisting of knowledge is in the vital airs' etc., which is the meaning of the word 'tvam' (you).

analyzed: prāṇa ādi bhinna śuddha tvaṃ padārtha jñānasya vākya artha sākṣātkāraḥ phalam iti āha kevala iti
translated: The result is the direct realization of the meaning of the sentence, of the knowledge of the pure meaning of 'tvam' (you), which is different from the vital airs, etc. He says: 'By the mere' (word 'tvam') etc.

original: saśarīratvasya satyatvātsamutthānamutkrāntiriti vyākhyeyaṃ na viveka ityāśaṅkyāhatathā viveketi /
analyzed: sa śarīra tvasya satya tvāt samutthānam utkrāntiḥ iti vyākhyeyam na vivekaḥ iti āśaṅkya āha tathā viveka iti
translated: Since the state of having a body is real, the arising should be explained as the departure, not as the discrimination. Fearing this, he says: 'Thus, in discrimination' etc.

analyzed: ukta śruti anusāreṇa iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: in accordance with the stated Vedic text.

analyzed: śarīreṣu aśarīram avasthitam iti śruteḥ aviveka mātra kalpitam sa śarīra tvam
translated: Since it is stated in the Vedic text that 'the bodiless one abides in the bodies', the state of having a body is merely imagined due to non-discrimination.

analyzed: atas vivekaḥ eva samutthānam iti arthaḥ
translated: Therefore, discrimination itself is the cause of manifestation.

original: nanu svakarmārjite śarīre bhogasyāparihāryatvātkathaṃ jīvata eva svarūpāvirbhāva ityata āhaśarīrastho 'pīti /
analyzed: nanu sva karma arjite śarīre bhogasya aparihārya tvāt katham jīvataḥ eva svarūpa āvirbhāvaḥ iti atas āha śarīra sthaḥ pi iti
translated: But since enjoyment is unavoidable in a body earned by one's own actions, how can there be manifestation of one's nature while still alive? To this he says: though dwelling in the body.

analyzed: aśarīra tva vat śarīra sthasya api bandha abhāva smṛteḥ jīvataḥ muktiḥ yuktā iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that liberation while alive is proper because of the remembrance of the absence of bondage even for one dwelling in the body, as if he were bodiless.

analyzed: aviruddhe śruti arthe sūtra śeṣaḥ yuktaḥ iti āha tasmāt iti
translated: When the meaning of the scriptural passage is not contradicted, the remainder of the sutra is proper. Thus he says: therefore.

analyzed: anyādṛśau satyau iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that they are of a different kind.

analyzed: jñāna ajñāna kṛtau āvirbhāva tirobhāvau iti sthite bhedaḥ pi aṃśa aṃśi tva kṛtaḥ nirastaḥ iti āha evam iti
translated: When it is established that manifestation and non-manifestation are due to knowledge and ignorance respectively, he says thus, the difference due to the relation of part and whole is also refuted.

analyzed: aṃśa ādi śūnyatvam asaṅga tvam  ātmā dravya tva vyāpya jāti śūnyaḥ vibhu tvāt
translated: Freedom from attachment is the absence of parts and so on.🔽The self is devoid of the universal that pervades substantiality, because it is all-pervading.

analyzed: vyoma vat iti ātma aikya siddheḥ bhedaḥ mithyā iti arthaḥ
translated: Like space, thus the oneness of the self is established, and difference is false. This is the meaning.

analyzed: prajāpati vākyāt ca bhedaḥ mithyā iti ākāṅkṣā pūrvakam āha kutas ca ityādinā
translated: And from the words of Prajapati, difference is false. Anticipating this, he says from what etc.

original: etadbhedasya satyatvameva nāstīti kuta ityanvayaḥ chāyāyāṃ brahmadṛṣṭiparamidaṃ vākyaṃ nābhedaparamityata āhanāpīti /
analyzed: etat bhedasya satya tvam eva na asti iti kutas iti anvayaḥ chāyāyām brahma dṛṣṭi param idam vākyam na abheda param iti atas āhanā api iti
translated: The meaning is that this sentence is about seeing Brahman in the shadow, not about non-difference. To this he says: not even.

original: yasya jñānātkṛtakṛtyatā sarvakāmaprāptistamātmānamanvicchāva iti pravṛttayorindravirocanayoryadyanātmacchāyāṃ prajāpatirbrūyāttadā mṛṣāvādi 🔽syādityarthaḥ /
analyzed: yasya jñānāt kṛtakṛtya tā sarva kāma prāptiḥ tam ātmānam anvicchāvaḥ iti pravṛttayoḥ indra virocanayoḥ yadi anātma chāyām prajāpatiḥ brūyāt tadā mṛṣāvādi  syāt iti arthaḥ
translated: We shall seek that Self, by knowing whom one becomes successful, who obtains all desires. When Prajāpati speaks to Indra and Virocana who have thus engaged, if he were to speak of the Self that is not the shadow, then he would be a speaker of falsehood. This is the meaning.

original: prathamavat dvitīyādiparyāye vyāvṛttāsvavasthāsu unusyūtātmā brahmatvenokta ityāhatatheti /
analyzed: prathama vat dvitīya ādi paryāye vyāvṛttāsu avasthāsu unusyūta ātmā brahma tvena uktaḥ iti āha tathā iti
translated: As in the first case, in the second and subsequent repetitions, the Self that is interwoven in the states that have been excluded is spoken of as Brahman. Thus he says.

analyzed: avasthā bhede yuktim āha kiñca iti
translated: Even in the difference of states, he gives the reason for the interweaving, saying And why?

analyzed: suṣuptau jñātuḥ vyāvṛttim āśaṅkya āha tathā tṛtīyaḥ iti
translated: Fearing the exclusion of the knower in deep sleep, he says So also in the third.

analyzed: saṣuptau nirvikalpa jñāna rūpaḥ ātmā asti iti atra bṛhadāraṇyaka śrutim āha nahi iti
translated: In deep sleep, the Self exists in the form of non-conceptual knowledge. Here he quotes the Brhadāraṇyaka śruti, saying Not so.

analyzed: buddheḥ sākṣiṇaḥ nāśaḥ na asti
translated: The witness of the intellect is not destroyed.

analyzed: na āśaka abhāvāt iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that there is no destroyer.

analyzed: etam avasthābhiḥ asaṅga tvena uktaḥ ātmā eva turīye brahmatvena uktaḥ iti āha tathā iti
translated: That Self, which has been spoken of as unattached to the states, is spoken of as Brahman in the fourth also. Thus he says.

analyzed: śruteḥ eka deśi vyākhyām dūṣayati kecid tu iti
translated: He refutes the explanation of some who are partial to the śruti, saying Some, however.

analyzed: jīva parayoḥ bhadāt iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The meaning is that the Self and the individual soul are different.

analyzed: śruti bādhāt mā evam iti āha teṣām iti
translated: He says No because of the contradiction of the śruti, saying Of them.

analyzed: saṃnihitaḥ jīvaḥ eva sarvanāma arthaḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that the pronoun refers only to the present individual soul.

analyzed: uktasya punaruktau bhūyaḥ iti yujyate
translated: And in the repetition of what has been stated, again is appropriate.

original: tava tu upakrāntaparamātmanaścaturtha evoktestadbāda ityāhabhūya iti /
analyzed: tava tu upakrānta paramātmanaḥ caturthe eva ukteḥ tad bādaḥ iti āha bhūyas iti
translated: But for you, since the fourth is stated about the supreme self that was introduced, that is a fault. He says again.
He concludes his own view that Brahman is to be understood by restating the self that is well-known in the world. He says therefore.

analyzed: vyākhyāna antara saṃbhavāt iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: because another explanation is possible.

analyzed: vilayanam śodhanam
translated: Dissolution is purification.

analyzed: vidyayā mahāvākyena iti yāvat
translated: Up to the point of the great statement by the knowledge.

original: ye tu saṃsāraṃ satyamicchanti teṣāmidaṃ śārīrakamevottaramityāhaapare tvityādinā /
analyzed: ye tu saṃsāram satyam icchanti teṣām idam śārīrakam eva uttaram iti āha apare tu ityādinā
translated: But for those who consider worldly existence to be real, this is the very reply of the Śārīraka. He says with the words others, however, and so on.

analyzed: śārīrakasya artham saṃkṣepaṇā upadiśati ekaḥ eva iti
translated: He teaches the meaning of the Śārīraka in brief with the words one alone.

analyzed: avidyā māyayoḥ bhedam nirasitum sāmānādhikaraṇyam
translated: In order to refute the difference between ignorance and illusion, there is co-reference.

analyzed: āvaraṇa vikṣepa śakti rūpa śabda pravṛtti nimitta bhedāt sahaprayogaḥ
translated: The simultaneous use is due to the difference in the reasons for the use of the word, which are the powers of obstruction and distraction.

original: brahmaivāvidyayā saṃsarati na tato 'nyo jīva iti śārīrakārtha ityarthaḥ /
analyzed: brahma eva avidyayā saṃsarati na tatas nyaḥ jīvaḥ iti śārīraka arthaḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning of the Śārīraka is that Brahman alone transmigrates due to ignorance, and there is no other self than that.

analyzed: tarhi sūtrakāraḥ kim iti bhedam brūte
translated: Then why does the author of the aphorisms speak of difference?

analyzed: tatra ahayaḥ tu iti
translated: There he says but those who, and so on.
In order to establish that the supreme self does not transmigrate, he strengthens the difference from the individual self.

analyzed: tasya asaṃsāri tva niścaya abhāve tad abheda uktau api jīvasya saṃsāri tva anapāyāt iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that if there is no certainty of its being not subject to worldly existence, then even if its non-difference is stated, the individual soul's subjection to worldly existence cannot be avoided.

analyzed: adhiṣṭhānasya kalpitāt bhede kalpitasya adhiṣṭhānāt na pṛthak sattvam iti āha jīvasya tu iti
translated: Even though the substratum is different from the imagined, the imagined does not have separate existence from the substratum. Thus he says: But of the individual soul...

analyzed: kalpita bheda anuvādasya phalam āha evam hi iti
translated: The result of stating the imagined difference is stated thus: For thus...

analyzed: sūtreṣu abhedaḥ na uktaḥ iti bhrāntim nirasyati pratipādyam iti
translated: In order to remove the misconception that non-difference is not stated in the scriptures, he says: The subject matter...

analyzed: ātmā iti tu upagacchanti ityādi sūtrāṇi ādi padārthaḥ
translated: The meaning of the word etc. is the aphorisms beginning with But they accept as the Self...

analyzed: nanu advaitasya śāstra artha tve dvaita apekṣa vidhi virodhaḥ tatra āha varṇitaḥ ca iti
translated: If non-duality is the meaning of the scriptures, there is contradiction with injunctions that depend on duality. There, he says: And it is stated...

original: advaitamajānataḥ kalpitadvaitāśrayā vidhayo na viduṣa iti sarvamupapannamityarthaḥ ////
analyzed: advaitam a jānataḥ kalpita dvaita āśrayāḥ vidhayaḥ na viduṣaḥ iti sarvam upapannam iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that for one who does not know non-duality, injunctions based on imagined duality are not for the knower, and thus everything is reasonable.🔽end

analyzed: e ns  start
translated: start

analyzed: anya arthaḥ ca parāmarśaḥ
translated: And the reference is for another purpose.

original: evaṃ prajāpativākye jīvānuvādena brahmaṇa evāpahatapāpmatvādyukterjīve tadasaṃbhavānna jīvo dahara ityuktam /
analyzed: evam prajāpati vākye jīva anuvādena brahmaṇaḥ eva apahatapāpma tva ādi ukteḥ jīve tad asaṃbhavāt na jīvaḥ daharaḥ iti uktam
translated: Thus, in the statement of Prajapati, Brahman alone is stated to have the qualities of being free from sin, etc., by superseding the individual soul. Since that is impossible for the individual soul, the individual soul is not the small one, as stated.

analyzed: tarhi jīva parāmarśasya kā gatiḥ iti atas āha anya arthaḥ ca iti
translated: Then what is the position of the reference to the individual soul? Therefore he says: And the reference is for another purpose.

analyzed: sūtram vyācaṣṭe atha ityādinā
translated: He explains the Sūtra beginning with atha (now).

analyzed: prakṛte dahare viśeṣaḥ guṇaḥ tad upadeśaḥ api na iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that in the context of the small one, there is a special quality, and even its teaching is not.

analyzed: tatra dahara vākya śeṣa rūpam saṃprasāda vākyam āśaṅkā pūrvakam dahara brahma paratvena vyācaṣṭe katham ityādinā
translated: There, regarding the passage on tranquility, which is a part of the passage on the small one, he explains it as referring to the Brahman of the small one, preceded by a doubt, with the words katham (how).🔽end

analyzed: e ns  start
translated: start

analyzed: alpa śruteḥ iti ced tat uktam
translated: If it is argued that it is due to the smallness of the scripture, that has been stated.

analyzed: upāsya tvāt alpatvam uktam iti vyākhyāya śrutyā nirastam iti artha antaram āha śrutyā eva ca idam iti
translated: Having explained that smallness is mentioned due to being the object of meditation, he states another meaning that it is refuted by scripture, with the words by scripture itself, this.

original: evaṃ daharavākyaṃ prajāpativākyaṃ ca saguṇe nirguṇe ca samanvitamiti siddham ////
analyzed: evam dahara vākyam prajāpati vākyam ca sa guṇe nirguṇe ca samanvitam iti siddham
translated: Thus, it is established that the passage on the small one and the passage on Prajapati are consistent with the qualified and the unqualified Brahman.🔽end

analyzed: e ns  start  anukṛteḥ tasya ca
translated: start🔽Because of its being a copy, and because of that.

analyzed: anukṛteḥ tasya ca
translated: Because of its being a copy, and because of that.

analyzed: muṇḍaka vākyam udāharati na tatra iti
translated: He cites the passage from the Mundaka, with Na tatra (not there).

analyzed: tasmin brahmaṇi viṣaye na bhāti
translated: In that Brahman as the object, it does not shine.

analyzed: tam na bhāsayati iti yāvat
translated: That is, it does not illuminate it.

original: yadā candrabhāskarādirna bhāsayati tadā alpadīpteragneḥ kā kathetyāhakuta iti /
analyzed: yadā candra bhāskara ādiḥ na bhāsayati tadā alpa dīpteḥ agneḥ kā kathā iti āha kutas iti
translated: And when the moon, sun, etc. do not shine, then what to speak of fire with little light? He says Kutaḥ (from where).

analyzed: kiñca sarvasya sūrya ādeḥ tad bhāsya tvāt na tad bhāsaka tvam iti āhatam eva iti
translated: Moreover, since everything, like the sun, is illuminated by that, it is not the illuminator of that. He says: That itself.

analyzed: anugamana vat anumānam svagatam iti śaṅkām nirasyati tasya iti
translated: To remove the doubt that inference is like following, independent, he says: Of that.

original: tatreti saptamyāḥ sati viṣaye ca sādhāraṇyātsaṃśayamāhatatreti /
analyzed: tatra iti saptamyāḥ sati viṣaye ca sādhāraṇyāt saṃśayam āha tatra iti
translated: There, because the locative case ending in tatra (in that) is common to both the existent object and the object of doubt, he states the doubt with tatra (there).

original: pūrvatrātmaśrutyādibalādākāśaśabdasya rūḍhityāgādīśvare vṛttirāśritā /🔽tathehāpi satisaptamībalādvartamānārthatyāgena yasminsati sūryādayo na bhāsyanti sa tejoviśeṣa upāsya iti bhaviṣyadarthe vṛttirāśrayaṇīyā /
analyzed: pūrvatra ātma śruti ādi balāt ākāśa śabdasya rūḍhi tyāgāt īśvare vṛttiḥ āśritā  tathā iha api sati saptamī balāt vartamāna artha tyāgena yasmin sati sūrya ādayaḥ na bhāsyanti sa tejaḥ viśeṣaḥ upāsyaḥ iti bhaviṣyat arthe vṛttiḥ āśrayaṇīyā
translated: In the previous section, the application of the word ākāśa (space) to God was accepted by abandoning its established meaning, based on the strength of the scriptural statement about the Self.🔽Similarly, here also, by the strength of the locative case ending in sati (in the existent), the application to the future meaning should be accepted, by abandoning the present meaning, that the special light in which the sun etc. are not illuminated is to be meditated upon.

original: adhunā bhāsamāne sūryādau na bhātīti virodhāditi dṛṣṭāntena pūrvapakṣayatitejodhāturiti /
analyzed: adhunā bhāsamāne sūrya ādau na bhāti iti virodhāt iti dṛṣṭāntena pūrvapakṣayati tejaḥ dhātuḥ iti
translated: Now, he presents the prima facie view with an example, that it does not shine in the shining sun etc., because of contradiction, with the element of light.

analyzed: tejaḥ dhānam
translated: The accumulation of light.

analyzed: nirguṇa svayam jyotiḥ ātma jñānam iti ubhayatra phalam  tejaḥ dhātu tve liṅgam āha tejaḥ dhātūnām iti
translated: The result is the knowledge of the attributeless, self-luminous Self in both cases.🔽In the case of being the element of light, he states the reason with tejo-dhātūnām (of the elements of light).

analyzed: yat tejasaḥ bhibhāvakam tat tejaḥ iti vyāptim āha tejaḥ svabhāvakam iti
translated: He states the pervasion that what is the superseder of light is light with tejaḥ-svabhāva-kam (having the nature of light).

original: yasminsati yanna bhāti tadanu tadbhātīti viruddhamityata āhaanubhānamiti /
analyzed: yasmin sati yat na bhāti tadanu tat bhāti iti viruddham iti atas āha anubhānam iti
translated: It is contradictory to say that when one thing exists, another does not shine, and then that it shines. To this he says shining after.

analyzed: tatas nikṛṣṭa bhānam vivakṣitam iti bhāvaḥ
translated: Therefore, the intended meaning is that the inferior shining is meant.

original: mukhyasaṃbhave vivakṣānupapatteḥ mukhyānubhānaliṅgātsarvabhāsakaḥ paramātmā svaprakāśako 'tra grāhya iti siddhāntamāhaprājña iti /
analyzed: mukhya saṃbhave vivakṣā anupapatteḥ mukhya anubhāna liṅgāt sarva bhāsakaḥ paramātmā sva prakāśakaḥ tra grāhyaḥ iti siddhāntam āha prājñaḥ iti
translated: Since it is not possible to intend something when the primary meaning is possible, he concludes that the illuminator of all, the Supreme Self, which is self-luminous, should be accepted here, based on the indication of primary shining, with the words The wise one.

analyzed: prājña tvam sva prakāśaka tvam bhāsaka tva artham uktam
translated: Wisdom, which is self-luminousness, is mentioned for the sake of being the illuminator.

analyzed: tatra śrutim āha bhā rūpaḥ iti
translated: In this regard, he quotes the scripture with the words In the form of light.

analyzed: māna abhāvāt ca tejaḥ dhātuḥ nā grāhyaḥ iti āha na tu iti
translated: And because there is no valid cognition, the luminous element cannot be accepted. He says But not.

analyzed: kiñca sūrya ādayaḥ tejaḥ ntara bhānam anu na bhānti
translated: Moreover, the sun and others do not shine after the shining of another light.

analyzed: tejaḥ tvāt
translated: Because they are light.

analyzed: pradīpa vat iti āha sama tvāt ca iti
translated: Like a lamp, he says And because of equality.

original: yo 'yamanukaroti sa tajjātīya iti niyamo nāstītyāhanāyamekānta iti /
analyzed: yaḥ yam anukaroti sa tad jātīyaḥ iti niyamaḥ na asti iti āhana ayam ekāntaḥ iti
translated: There is no rule that one who imitates is of the same kind. He says This is not absolute.

analyzed: paunaruktyam āśaṅkya ukta anuvāda pūrvakam sūtra uktam hetu antaram vyācaṣṭe anukṛteḥ iti
translated: Suspecting redundancy, he explains the other reason stated in the sutra, preceded by a restatement of what has been said, with the words Because of imitation.

analyzed: tam eva bhāntam iti evakāra uktam tad bhānam vinā sarvasya pṛthak bhāna abhāva rūpam anubhānam anukṛteḥ iti anena uktam tasya ca iti
translated: The shining of that, mentioned by the word 'that' in 'that shining one', is the non-shining, which is the absence of the separate shining of everything without that shining, is stated by the word 'non-shining' in 'non-shining'. And that is stated by the word 'manifestation' in 'manifestation'.

analyzed: sarva bhāsaka tvam uktam iti apaunaruktyam iti arthaḥ
translated: And the statement of its being the illuminator of all is not a repetition, is the meaning.

analyzed: ātmanaḥ sūrya ādi bhāsaka tvam śruti antara prasiddham aviruddham ca iti āha tat devāḥ iti
translated: The statement of the Self being the illuminator of the sun etc. is well-known from another Vedic text and is not contradictory, thus he says 'that god'.

analyzed: sarva śabdaḥ prakṛta sūrya ādi vācaka tvena vyākhyātaḥ
translated: The word 'all' is explained as denoting the sun etc. mentioned in the context.

analyzed: saṃprati tasya asaṃkucat vṛtti tām matvā artha antaram āha athavā iti
translated: Now, considering its unrestricted nature, he states another meaning with 'or'.

original: tatreti sarvanāmaśrutyā prakṛtaṃ brahma grāhyamityāhana tatra sūrya iti /
analyzed: tatra iti sarvanāma śrutyā prakṛtam brahma grāhyam iti āha na tatra sūryaḥ iti

translated: The connection of words is unavoidable as non-eternal due to the non-eternality of the meanings in the form of manifestations.

analyzed: tasmāt pauruṣeya saṃbandha sāpekṣa tvāt prāmāṇya virodhaḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: Therefore, the meaning is that there is a contradiction with the validity due to the dependence on the connection with human effort.

original: naca vyaktināmanityatve 'pi ghaṭatvādijātisamavāyavacchabdasaṃbandho 'pi nityaḥ syāditi vācyaṃ /
analyzed: naca vyaktinām anitya tve pi ghaṭa tva ādi jāti samavāya vat śabda saṃbandhaḥ pi nityaḥ syāt iti vācyam
translated: And it cannot be said that even when the manifestations are non-eternal, the connection with words would be eternal like the inherence of the universal 'pot-ness' etc.

analyzed: ubhaya āśrita saṃbandhasya anyatara abhāve sthiti ayogena dṛṣṭānta asidveḥ iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The meaning is that the relation which depends on both cannot remain when one of them is absent, so the example is not established.

original: yathā gotvādayo gavādiśabdavācyāstathā vasutvādyākṛtayo vasvādiśabdārthā na vyaktya iti pariharatinetyādinā /
analyzed: yathā go tva ādayaḥ gavā ādi śabda vācyāḥ tathā vasu tva ādi ākṛtayaḥ vasu ādi śabda arthāḥ na vyaktyaḥ iti pariharati na ityādinā
translated: Just as cowness etc. are denoted by the word 'cow' etc., in the same way, the forms characterized by Vasutva etc. are the meanings of the words 'Vasus' etc., not the manifestations. He answers with 'No' etc.

original: śabdānāṃ tadarthānāṃ jātīnāṃ ca nityatvāttatsaṃbandho 'pi nitya iti pratipādayatinahītyādinā /
analyzed: śabdānām tad arthānām jātīnām ca nitya tvāt tad saṃbandhaḥ api nityaḥ iti pratipādayati nahi ityādinā
translated: He explains that the relation is also eternal because the words, their meanings, and the universals are eternal, with the words For, etc.

analyzed: vyakti nāma ānantyāt iti
translated: Due to the infinite number of individuals.

original: naca gotvāvacchedena vyaktiṣu śaktiḥ sugraheti vācyaṃ /
analyzed: naca go tva avacchedena vyaktiṣu śaktiḥ sugrahā iti vācyam
translated: And it cannot be said that the power with regard to individuals is easily grasped by the restriction of being a cow.

original: sāmānyasyāpratyāsattitvena sarvavyaktyupasthityabhāvāt /🔽gotvaṃ śakyatāvacchedakamiti grahāpekṣayā gotvaṃ śakyamiti lāghavāt /
analyzed: go tvam śakya tā avacchedakam iti graha apekṣayā go tvam śakyam iti lāghavāt
translated: Because the universal is not a proximate cause, and all individuals are not present.🔽Because it is simpler to grasp that being a cow is the qualifier of what is possible, rather than that being a cow is what is possible.

analyzed: nirūḍha ajahat lakṣaṇayā vyakteḥ lābhena anya labhya tva abhāvāt ca iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The idea is that there is no other way of obtaining the individual through the figurative meaning that does not abandon the original meaning.

analyzed: yat vā kevala vyaktiṣu śaktiḥ atra nirasyate
translated: Or, here only the power with regard to individuals is being refuted.
The knowledge of inconsistency.

analyzed: vinā eva vyakteḥ śabda śakti āyatta jāti jñāna viṣaya tvena ubhaya śakteḥ āvaśyaka tvāt
translated: Because, even without the power of the word with regard to the individual, the universal must be known through the power of the word, and both powers are necessary.

analyzed: tathāca nitya jāti tādātmyena vyakteḥ anādi tvāt tad saṃbandhaḥ pi anādiḥ
translated: And thus, because the individual is beginningless by its identity with the eternal universal, its relation is also beginningless.

analyzed: satkārya vādāt
translated: Because of the doctrine of satkāryavāda.

original: ata eva vākyavṛttau tattvamasyādivākye bhāgalakṣaṇoktā yujyate /
analyzed: atas eva vākya vṛttau tattvamasi ādi vākye bhāga lakṣaṇa uktā yujyate
translated: For this very reason, the definition of a part in the case of sentences is appropriate in the sentence That art thou, etc.
If the mere universal were denoted, then the indivisible meaning would not be a part of what is denoted.

original: 'ataḥprabhavāt'iti sūtrasvārasyācca kevalavyaktiśaktinirāsa iti gamyate /🔽kevalavyaktivacanāḥ khalu ḍitthādiśabdā arthānantarabhāvinaḥ sāṃketikāḥ gavādiśabdāstu
analyzed: atas prabhavāt iti sūtra svārasyāt ca kevala vyakti śakti nirāsaḥ iti gamyate  kevala vyakti vacanāḥ khalu ḍittha ādi śabdāḥ artha anantara bhāvinaḥ sāṃketikāḥ go ādi śabdāḥ tu
translated: And because of the natural meaning of the aphorism 'ataḥ prabhāvāt', it is understood that the mere individual's potency is excluded.🔽For words like 'dittha' etc. which denote mere individuals are conventional, occurring after the meaning, but words like 'go' etc.

original: vyaktiprabhavahetutvena prāgevasandhīti na vyaktimātravacanāḥ sāṃketikāḥ kintu sthūlasūkṣmabhāvenānusyūtavyaktyavinābhūtasāmānyavacanā iti
analyzed: vyakti prabhava hetu tvena prāk eva sandhi iti na vyakti mātra vacanāḥ sāṃketikāḥ kintu sthūla sūkṣma bhāvena anusyūta vyakti avinābhūta sāmānya vacanāḥ iti
translated: are not conventional denoters of mere individuals, but rather denoters of the universal which is inseparable from the individual that is continuous in gross and subtle form, since they are the cause of the origin of the individual, existing even before the convention.

analyzed: na ca indra ādi vyakteḥ ekatvena jāti abhāvāt ākāśa śabda vat indra candra ādi śabdaḥ kevala vyakti vacanāḥ iti sāṃpratam
translated: And it is not right to say that words like 'indra' and 'chandra' denote mere individuals, like the word 'ākāśa', because there is no class due to the oneness of the individual 'indra' etc.

analyzed: atīta anāgata vyakti bhedena jāti upapatteḥ iti alam prapañcena
translated: The class is established by the difference of individuals in the past and future. Enough of this elaboration.

analyzed: dṛṣṭāntam upasaṃhṛtya dārṣṭāntikam āha vyaktiṣu ityādinā ākṛtiḥ jātiḥ
translated: Having concluded the example, he applies it to the case in point with 'vyaktiṣu' etc. 'Ākṛti' is class.

analyzed: nanu kā sā vyaktiḥ
translated: Now, what is that individual?

analyzed: yat anugata indra tva ādi jātiḥ śabda arthaḥ syāt iti atas āha ākṛti viśeṣaḥ tu iti
translated: That which is the basis of the class 'indra-hood' etc. would be the meaning of the word. To this he says 'ākriti-viśeṣaḥ tu'.

analyzed: vajrahastaḥ purandaraḥ ityādibhyaḥ iti arthaḥ  indra ādi śabdānām jātiḥ indra ādiṣu pravṛtti nimittam iti uktvā upādhi nimittam āha sthāna iti
translated: The meaning is from such passages as Vajrahasta, Purandara (Indra).🔽Having stated that the class is the reason for the application of words like Indra to Indra and so on, he says in place to state the reason based on the limiting adjunct.

analyzed: vyakti pralaye pi sthānasya sthāyi tvāt śabda artha saṃbandha nitya tā iti atas āha tatas ca iti
translated: Even when the individual dissolves, the permanence of the place makes the connection between word and meaning permanent. Therefore he says and from that.

analyzed: uktam pūrva apara virodham pariharati na ca iti
translated: He resolves the contradiction between the earlier and later statements by saying not so.

analyzed: śabdaḥ nimittam iti avirodham matvā sūtra śeṣam avatārayati katham punar iti
translated: Considering that there is no contradiction in saying that the word is the reason, he introduces the remainder of the sutra by saying How then?.

analyzed: smṛtyā sva prāmāṇya artham mūlaśrutiḥ anumīyate iti anumānam smṛtiḥ
translated: Smriti is inference, in which the original Vedic text is inferred for the sake of establishing its own validity.

analyzed: ete asṛgram indavaḥ tiras pavitram āśavaḥ
translated: These Soma juices have flowed through the purifying sieve, swift,

analyzed: viśvāni asya abhisaubhagā  iti etat mantra sthaiḥ padaiḥ smṛtvā brahmā deva ādīn asṛjat
translated: bringing all good fortune to him.🔽Brahma created the gods and others by remembering with these words in the mantra.

analyzed: tatra ete iti padam sarvanāma tvāt devānām smārakam
translated: There, the word etai (these) reminds of the gods because it is a pronoun.

original: asṛgrudhiraṃ tatpradhāne dehe ramanta iti asṛgrā manuṣyāḥ /
analyzed: asṛj rudhiram tad pradhāne dehe ramante iti asṛj rāḥ manuṣyāḥ
translated: Humans are called asrigara because they delight in the body which has blood as its main constituent.

analyzed: candra sthānām pitṛṇām indu śabdaḥ smārakaḥ
translated: The word indu (moon) reminds of the ancestors who reside in the moon.

original: pavitraṃ somaṃ svāntastiraskurvatāṃ grahāṇāṃ tiraḥ pavitraśabdaḥ /
analyzed: pavitram somam su antar tiraskurvatām grahāṇām tiras pavitra śabdaḥ
translated: The word 'tiras' (beyond) in the expression 'tiras-pavitra' (beyond the strainer) refers to the Soma-cups which are beyond the strainer.

analyzed: ṛcaḥ śruvatām stotrāṇām gīti rūpāṇām āśu śabdaḥ
translated: The word 'ashu' (swift) refers to the Stotras (hymns) which are in the form of songs and are sung by the Rishis.

analyzed: ṛci adhyūḍham sāma eti śruteḥ
translated: Because of the Vedic text 'Sama is based on the Riks'.

analyzed: stotra anantaram prayogam viśatām śāstrāṇām viśva śabdaḥ
translated: The word 'Vishva' (all) refers to the Shastras which enter into practice after the Stotras.

analyzed: sarvatra saubhāgya yuktānām abhisaubhaga śabdaḥ smārakaḥ iti chandoga brāhmaṇa vākya arthaḥ
translated: The word 'Abhisaubhaga' (most fortunate) is a reminder of all that is associated with good fortune. This is the meaning of the Chandogya Brahmana text.

original: sa prajāpatirmanasā vācaṃ trayīṃ mithunaṃ samabhavat manovāgrūpaṃ mithunaṃ saṃbhāvitavān /
analyzed: sa prajāpatiḥ manasā vācam trayīm mithunam samabhavat manaḥ vāc rūpam mithunam saṃbhāvitavān
translated: That Prajapati became a couple with the mind and speech, the three Vedas. He brought about a couple in the form of mind and speech.

analyzed: manasā trayī prakāśitām sṛṣṭim ālocitavān iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that he mentally conceived the creation illuminated by the three Vedas.

analyzed: raśmiḥ iti eva ādityam asṛjata eti ādi śrutiḥ ādi śabda arthaḥ
translated: The meaning of the word 'adi' (etc.) is the Vedic text beginning with 'He created the sun as the ray'.

analyzed: saṃpradāyaḥ guru śiṣya paramparā adhyayanam
translated: Sampradaya is the study through the succession of teachers and students.

analyzed: saṃsthāḥ avasthāḥ
translated: Samsthas are the states.

analyzed: yā prajāpati sṛṣṭiḥ sā śabda pūrvikā
translated: That creation of Prajapati is preceded by sound.

analyzed: sṛṣṭi tvāt
translated: Because it is a creation.

analyzed: pratyakṣa ghaṭa ādi vat iti pratyakṣa anumānābhyām iti asya ārta antaram āha api ca iti
translated: Like a pot etc. which are directly perceived. The meaning of this is that it is by perception and inference. He says another meaning of this in 'Moreover'.

analyzed: atas prabhava tva prasaṅgāt śabda svarūpam vaktum uktam ākṣipati kimātmakam iti
translated: Therefore, due to the non-applicability of the origination, he raises the question What is its nature? in order to state the nature of sound.

analyzed: varṇa rūpam tad atirikta sphoṭa rūpam vā iti kim śabda arthaḥ
translated: The meaning of the word what is whether it has the form of letters or the form of sphoṭa apart from that.

original: tatra varṇānāmanityatvātsphoṭasya cāsattvānna jagaddhetutvamityākṣepe dvitīyapakṣaṃ vaiyākaraṇo gṛhṇātisphoṭamiti /
analyzed: tatra varṇānām anitya tvāt sphoṭasya ca asattvāt na jagat hetutvam iti ākṣepe dvitīya pakṣam vaiyākaraṇaḥ gṛhṇāti sphoṭam iti
translated: There, since letters are impermanent and sphoṭa is non-existent, it is not the cause of the world. When this objection is raised, the grammarian accepts the second view, saying sphoṭa.

original: sphuṭyate varṇairvyajyata iti sphoṭovarṇābhivyaṅgyor'thastasya vyañjako gavādiśabdo nityastamabhipretyedamucyata iti pūrveṇānvayaḥ /
analyzed: sphuṭyate varṇaiḥ vyajyate iti sphoṭaḥ varṇa abhivyaṅgyaḥ arthaḥ tasya vyañjakaḥ gavādi śabdaḥ nityaḥ tam abhipretya idam ucyate iti pūrveṇa anvayaḥ
translated: The meaning is that the word sphoṭa is uttered with the intention that the eternal word go etc. is that which manifests the meaning that is manifested by the sphoṭa, which is manifested by the letters. The connection is with the previous statement.

original: sa evādyapakṣaṃ dūṣayativarṇeti /🔽so 'yaṃ gakāra iti pratyabhijñayā varṇanityatvasiddhernānupapattirityata āhautpanneti /
analyzed: saḥ eva ādya pakṣam dūṣayati varṇa iti  saḥ yam gakāraḥ iti pratyabhijñayā varṇa nitya tva siddheḥ na anupapattiḥ iti atas āha utpanna iti
translated: He himself refutes the first view, saying letters etc.🔽Since the eternality of letters is established by recognition as this is the letter 'ga', there is no inconsistency. To this he says when produced etc.

original: tāratvamandratvādiviruddhadharmavattvena tāro gakāro mandro gakāra iti pratīyamānagakārasya bhedānumānātpratyabhijñāgatvajātiviṣayetyarthaḥ
analyzed: tāra tva mandra tva ādi viruddha dharmavat tvena tāraḥ gakāraḥ mandraḥ gakāraḥ iti pratīyamāna gakārasya bheda anumānāt pratyabhijñā ga tva jāti viṣayā iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that since the letter ga is cognized as the letter 'ga' is high and the letter 'ga' is low, and since the inference of the difference of the cognized letter ga is due to its having contradictory properties such as highness and lowness, the recognition is with regard to the universal ga in the letter ga.

original: nanu viruddhadharmajñānaṃ dhvanyupādhikaṃ bhrama ityata āhanaceti /
analyzed: nanu viruddha dharma jñānam dhvani upādhikam bhramaḥ iti atas āha na ca iti
translated: But the cognition of contradictory properties is a delusion due to the superimposition of sound. To this he says: And not so, etc.

original: tathāca varṇānāmanityatvānna jagaddhetutvamiti bhāvaḥ kiñca teṣāmarthabodhakatvāyogātsphoṭo 'ṅgīkārya ityāhanaca varṇebhya ityādinā /🔽vyabhicārādekasmādvarṇādarthapratītyadarśanāt /
analyzed: tathāca varṇānām anitya tvāt na jagat hetutvam iti bhāvaḥ kiñca teṣām artha bodhaka tva ayogāt sphoṭaḥ ṅgīkāryaḥ iti āha na ca varṇebhyaḥ ityādinā  vyabhicārāt ekasmāt varṇāt artha pratīti adarśanāt
translated: And thus, because of the impermanence of the letters, there is no causality of the world. This is the idea. And further, because of the impossibility of their conveying the meaning, the sphoṭa must be accepted. He says this beginning with: And not from the letters, etc.

analyzed: varṇa antara vaiyarthya prasaṅgāt ca iti arthaḥ
translated: Because of the fallacy of over-extension, and because of the non-apprehension of the cognition of the meaning from a single letter,🔽the other letters would be useless. This is the meaning.

original: tarhi varṇānāṃ samudāyo bodhaka ityāśaṅkya kṣaṇikānāṃ sa nāstītyāhanaceti /
analyzed: tarhi varṇānām samudāyaḥ bodhakaḥ iti āśaṅkya kṣaṇikānām sa na asti iti āha na ca iti
translated: Then, if it is supposed that the aggregate of letters is the conveyor of meaning, he says: And not so, etc.

original: varṇānāṃ svataḥ sāhityābhāve 'pi saṃskāralakṣaṇāpūrvadvārā sāhityamāgneyādiyāgānāmiveti śaṅkatepūrveti /
analyzed: varṇānām svatas sāhitya abhāve pi saṃskāra lakṣaṇa apūrva dvārā sāhityam āgneya ādi yāgānām iva iti śaṅkate pūrva iti
translated: Even though there is no natural association of the letters, there is association through the prior impression characterized as a latent impression, just as in the case of the Agniṣṭoma and other sacrifices. He doubts this in the verse beginning with: The prior, etc.

analyzed: kim ayam saṃskāraḥ varṇaiḥ janitaḥ pūrva ākhyaḥ kaścid
translated: Is this impression called apūrva produced by the letters?

analyzed: uta varṇa anubhava janitaḥ bhāvanā ākhyaḥ
translated: Or is it called bhāvanā produced by the experience of the letters?

analyzed: na ādyaḥ māna abhāvāt
translated: Not the first, because there is no evidence.

analyzed: kiñca ayam ajñātaḥ jñātaḥ vā artha dhī hetuḥ
translated: Moreover, is this impression the cause of the cognition of the meaning when unknown, or when known?

analyzed: na ādyaḥ iti āha tat na iti
translated: He says: That is not so, etc.

analyzed: saṃskāra sahitaḥ śabdaḥ jñātaḥ eva artha dhī hetuḥ
translated: A word accompanied by an impression is the cause of the cognition of the meaning only when known.

analyzed: saṃbandha grahaṇam apekṣya bodhaka tvāt
translated: Because it is a means of knowing, in dependence on the apprehension of the relation.

analyzed: dhūma ādi vat iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is like smoke etc.

original: dvitīye kiṃ pratyakṣeṇa jñāta uta kāryaliṅgena /
analyzed: dvitīye kim pratyakṣeṇa jñātaḥ uta kārya liṅgena
translated: In the second case, is it known by perception or by the inferential mark of effect?

analyzed: na ādyaḥ iti āha na ca iti
translated: He rejects the first by saying and that is not so.

analyzed: dvitīyam śaṅkate kāryā iti
translated: He raises the doubt about the second by saying effect.

original: kāryamarthadhīstasyāṃ jātāyāṃ saṃskārapratyayaḥ tasmiñjāte seti parasparāśrayeṇa dūṣayatineti /
analyzed: kāryam artha dhīḥ tasyām jātāyām saṃskāra pratyayaḥ tasmin jāte sā iti paraspara āśrayeṇa dūṣayati na iti
translated: When the cognition of the object arises from that, the impression is the condition. When that arises, it is so. He criticizes it as a mutual dependence by saying no.

original: padārthasmaraṇasyāpi padajñānāntarabhāvitvāttena saṃskārasahitāntyavarṇātmakapadasya jñānaṃ na yuktamityakṣarārthaḥ /
analyzed: padārtha smaraṇasya api pada jñāna antara bhāvi tvāt tena saṃskāra sahita antya varṇa ātmaka padasya jñānam na yuktam iti akṣara arthaḥ
translated: The meaning of the word is that the recollection of the meaning of a word also exists after the knowledge of the word, so the knowledge of the word consisting of the final letter along with the impression is not proper.

analyzed: api śabdaḥ paraspara āśraya dyotana arthaḥ
translated: The word also is to indicate mutual dependence.

analyzed: etena nirastaḥ  tasya varṇa smṛti mātra hetu tvena artha dhī hetu tva ayogāt
translated: By this, the theory of impression as the cause of existence is also rejected.🔽Because it is not proper for it to be the cause of the cognition of the object, being only the cause of the recollection of the letter.

analyzed: na ca antya varṇa sāhityāt artha dhī hetu tvam
translated: And it cannot be said that the cognition of the object is caused by the final letter along with the impression.

analyzed: kevala saṃskārasya tu varṇa smṛti hetu tvam iti vācyam
translated: But it must be said that the impression alone is the cause of the recollection of the letter.

analyzed: artha dhī pūrva kāle bhāvanāyāḥ jñāna abhāvena artha dhī hetu tva ayogāt
translated: And it is not proper for it to be the cause of the cognition of the object, because there is no knowledge of the impression at the time before the cognition of the object.

original: naca varṇasmaraṇenānumitā sā antyavarṇasahitārthadhīheturiti vācyaṃ /🔽tatkāryasya kramikasya varṇasmaraṇasyāpyantyavarṇānubhavānantarabhāvitvena tenānumitabhāvanānāmantyavarṇasāhityābhāvāditi bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: na ca varṇa smaraṇena anumitā sā antya varṇa sahita artha dhī hetuḥ iti vācyam  tad kāryasya kramikasya varṇa smaraṇasya api antya varṇa anubhava anantara bhāvi tvena tena anumita bhāvanānām antya varṇa sāhitya abhāvāt iti bhāvaḥ
translated: And it cannot be said that it is inferred from the recollection of the letters, and that it is the cause of the cognition of the meaning along with the final letter.🔽The idea is that the recollection of the letters, which is the effect of that [inference], also occurs after the experience of the final letter, and therefore the inferred cognition does not have the final letter along with it.

analyzed: varṇānām artha bodhaka tva saṃbhave phalam āha tasmāt iti
translated: When it is possible for the letters to convey the meaning, he states the result [of that possibility] with tasmāt [verse 21].

original: sphoṭe 'pi kiṃ mānamityāśaṅkyaikaṃ padamiti pratyakṣapramāṇamityāhasa ceti /
analyzed: sphoṭe pi kim mānam iti āśaṅkya ekam padam iti pratyakṣa pramāṇam iti āha sa ca iti
translated: Fearing that someone might ask What is the evidence for the sphoṭa?, he says that the evidence is perception, with sa ca [verse 22].

original: yathā ratnatattvaṃ bahubhiścākṣuṣapratyayaiḥ sphuṭaṃ bhāsate tathā gavādipadasphoṭo
analyzed: yathā ratna tattvam bahubhiḥ cākṣuṣa pratyayaiḥ sphuṭam bhāsate tathā gavādi pada sphoṭaḥ
translated: Just as the essence of a gem shines clearly through many visual perceptions, in the same way, the sphoṭa of the word cow etc.,

original: gakāradyekaikavarṇakṛtapratyayaiḥ sphoṭaviṣayairāhitāḥ saṃskārā bījaṃ yasmin citte
analyzed: gakāra di ekaika varṇa kṛta pratyayaiḥ sphoṭa viṣayaiḥ āhitāḥ saṃskārāḥ bījam yasmin citte
translated: is the seed in that mind in which the impressions created by the perceptions produced by each letter such as ga etc., which have the sphoṭa as their object,

analyzed: tasmin antya varṇa kṛta pratyayena janitaḥ paripākaḥ ntyaḥ saṃskāraḥ yasmin tasmin pratyayini
translated: in that mind of the person who has the perception produced by the final letter, the final impression generated by that perception,

translated: and that God is the cause of the world, etc. This is the meaning.

original: yajñena pūrvasukṛtena vāco vedasya lābhayogyatāṃ prāptāḥ santo yājñikāstāmṛṣiṣu sthitāṃ labdhavanta iti mantrārthaḥ /
analyzed: yajñena pūrva sukṛtena vācaḥ vedasya lābha yogya tām prāptāḥ santaḥ yājñikāḥ tām ṛṣiṣu sthitām labdhavantaḥ iti mantra arthaḥ
translated: The meaning of the mantra is that the sacrificers, who have attained the eligibility to obtain the Veda, the speech, by their previous good deeds through sacrifice, have obtained it that abides in the sages.

analyzed: anuvinnām upalabdhām
translated: They have obtained it through the Anuvamsa.

analyzed: pūrvam avāntarakalpa ādau
translated: Previously, at the beginning of the intermediate kalpa.

analyzed: e ns
translated: End.

analyzed: start
translated: Start.

analyzed: samāna nāma rūpa tvāt ca avṛttau api avirodhaḥ darśanāt smṛteḥ ca
translated: And because of the sameness of name and form, there is no contradiction even in repetition, as seen and as remembered.

analyzed: nanu mahāpralaye jāteḥ api asattvāt śabda artha saṃbandha anitya tvam iti āśaṅkya āha samāna iti
translated: Now, if it be objected that, since the universal also is non-existent when the great dissolution takes place, the connection of word and meaning must be non-eternal,—the author replies: ‘In the same way, etc.’

analyzed: sūtra nirasyām śaṅkām āha atha api iti
translated: He states the doubt which is to be set aside by the Sūtra: ‘Even so, etc.’

analyzed: vyakti saṃtatyā jātīnām avāntara pralaye sattvāt saṃbandhaḥ tiṣṭhati
translated: Since the universals, through the continuity of the individuals, exist in the minor dissolution, the connection remains.

original: vyavahārāvicchedājjñāyate ceti vedasyānapekṣatvena prāmāṇye na kaścidvirodhaḥ syāt /
analyzed: vyavahāra avicchedāt jñāyate ca iti vedasya anapekṣa tvena prāmāṇye na kaścid virodhaḥ syāt
translated: And since the continuity of usage is known, there would be no contradiction if the Veda were authoritative by itself, without dependence on anything else.

original: nirlepalaye tu saṃbandhanāśāt punaḥ sṛṣṭau kenacitpuṃsā saṃketaḥ kartavya iti puruṣabuddhisāpekṣatvena vedasyāprāmāṇyaṃ /
analyzed: nirlepa laye tu saṃbandha nāśāt punar sṛṣṭau kenacid puṃsā saṃketaḥ kartavyaḥ iti puruṣa buddhi sāpekṣa tvena vedasya aprāmāṇyam
translated: But in the case of the dissolution without residue, there would be destruction of the connection; and in the new creation, the convention would have to be made by some person. Thus, the Veda would be non-authoritative, being dependent on the human intellect.

analyzed: adhyāpakasya āśrayasya nāśāt āśritasya tasya anitya tvam ca prāptam iti arthaḥ
translated: And the Veda would be non-eternal, because of the destruction of the teacher, its substratum. This is the meaning.

analyzed: mahāpralaye pi nirlepa layaḥ siddhaḥ
translated: Even in the great dissolution, the dissolution without residue is not established.

analyzed: satkārya vādāt
translated: Because of the doctrine of the effect being existent in the cause.

original: tathāca saṃskārātmanā śabdārthatatsaṃbandhānāṃ satāmeva punaḥ sṛṣṭāvabhivyakternānityatvam /
analyzed: tathā ca saṃskāra ātmanā śabda artha tad saṃbandhānām satām eva punar sṛṣṭau abhivyakteḥ na anitya tvam
translated: And thus, the word, the meaning, and their connection, being existent in the form of impressions, are only manifested again in the new creation. Therefore, they are not non-eternal.

analyzed: abhivyaktānām pūrva kalpīya nāma rūpa samāna tvāt na saṃketaḥ kenacid kāryaḥ
translated: And since the manifested things are the same as the name and form of the previous Kalpa, no convention need be made by anyone.

original: viṣamasṛṣṭau hi saṃketāpekṣā na tulyasṛṣṭāviti pariharatitatredamityādinā /
analyzed: viṣama sṛṣṭau hi saṃketa apekṣā na tulya sṛṣṭau iti pariharati tatra idam ityādinā
translated: For in the creation of diversity, there is dependence on convention, but not in the creation of equality. To answer this, he says In that case and so on.

analyzed: nanu ādya sṛṣṭau saṃketaḥ kenacid kāryaḥ iti atas āha tadā api iti
translated: But if it is asked by whom was the convention made in the first creation, he says Even then.

analyzed: mahā sarga pralaya pravṛttau api iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: even when the great creation and dissolution are going on.

original: nanvastvanādisaṃsāre saṃbandhasyānāditvaṃ tathāpi mahāpralayavyavadhānādasmaraṇe kathaṃ vedārthavyavahāraḥ /
analyzed: nanu astu anādi saṃsāre saṃbandhasya anādi tvam tathā api mahāpralaya vyavadhānāt asmaraṇe katham veda artha vyavahāraḥ
translated: But even if the relation in the beginningless worldly existence is beginningless, how can there be usage of the meaning of the Veda when it is not remembered due to the obstruction of the great dissolution?

analyzed: tatra āha anādau ca iti
translated: To that, he says In the beginningless and so on.

analyzed: na kaścid virodhaḥ
translated: There is no contradiction at all.

analyzed: śabda artha saṃbandha smaraṇa ādeḥ iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The rest is: due to the remembrance and so on of the relation between word and meaning.

analyzed: svāpa prabodhayoḥ laya sarga asiddhim āśaṅkya śrutim āha svāpa iti
translated: Fearing that the dissolution and creation at the time of sleep are not established, he quotes the scripture In sleep.

original: atha tadā suṣuptau prāṇe paramātmani jīva ekībhavati enaṃ prāṇaṃ sa jīvaḥ tadaitīti śeṣaḥ /
analyzed: atha tadā suṣuptau prāṇe paramātmani jīvaḥ ekībhavati enam prāṇam sa jīvaḥ tadā eti iti śeṣaḥ
translated: Then, in that sleep, the individual self becomes one with the supreme self in the vital breath. The individual self goes to that vital breath, this is the remainder.

analyzed: etasmāt prātmanaḥ
translated: From that self.

analyzed: āyatanam golakam
translated: The abode is the body.

analyzed: ānantarye pañcamī ityādyā draṣṭavyā
translated: The fifth case is to be seen in the sense of immediacy.

original: svapnavatkalpitasyājñātasattvābhāvāt darśanaṃ sṛṣṭiḥ adarśanaṃ laya iti dṛṣṭisṛṣṭipakṣaḥ śrutyabhipreta iti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: svapna vat kalpitasya ajñāta sattva abhāvāt darśanam sṛṣṭiḥ adarśanam layaḥ iti dṛṣṭi sṛṣṭi pakṣaḥ śruti abhipretaḥ iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The meaning is that the view that creation is seeing and dissolution is non-seeing is the view intended by the scripture, because the imagined is not known to exist like in a dream.

analyzed: dṛṣṭānta vaiṣamyam āśaṅkya pariharati syāt ityādinā
translated: Anticipating the inequality of the example, he replies with it may be and so on.

analyzed: aviruddham anusandhāna ādikam iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The meaning is that the recollection and so on are not contradictory.

analyzed: hiraṇyagarbha ādayaḥ pūrva kalpa anusaṃdhāna śūnyaḥ
translated: Hiranyagarbha and others are devoid of the recollection of the previous kalpa.

analyzed: saṃsāri tvāt
translated: Because they are transmigrating beings.

analyzed: asmāt āt iva iti āśaṅkya āha yadi api iti
translated: Fearing that this is the beginning of the argument, he says even though.

original: iti yadyapi tathāpi na prākṛtavaditi yojanā /
analyzed: iti yadi api tathā api na prākṛta vat iti yojanā
translated: The construction is: even though this is so, still it is not like the ordinary person.

analyzed: jñāna ādeḥ nikarṣa vat utkarṣaḥ pi aṅgīkāryaḥ
translated: The excellence of knowledge and so on must also be accepted, like the decrease.

original: bādhābhāvāditi nyāyānugṛhītaśrutyādibhiḥ sāmānyato dṛṣṭānumānaṃ bādhyamityāhayathā hītyādinā /
analyzed: bādhā abhāvāt iti nyāya anugṛhīta śruti ādibhiḥ sāmānyatas dṛṣṭa anumānam bādhyam iti āha yathā hi ityādinā
translated: The inference of general perception is to be refuted by the scriptures and so on, which are supported by the principle that there is no contradiction, he says just as and so on.

original: nanu tathāpi pūrvakalpeśvarāṇāṃ muktatvādasminkalpe ko 'nusaṃdhātetyata āhatataśceti /
analyzed: nanu tathā api pūrva kalpa īśvarāṇām mukta tvāt asmin kalpe kaḥ nusaṃdhātā iti atas āha tatas ca iti
translated: But even then, since the lords of the previous kalpas are liberated, who is the recollecter in this kalpa? Therefore he says and from that.

analyzed: jñāna ādi utkarṣāt iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is from the excellence of knowledge and so on.

analyzed: muktebhyaḥ nye nusaṃdhātāraḥ iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The meaning is that others than the liberated ones are the recollecters.

analyzed: parameśvara anugṛhītānām jñāna atiśaye pūrva ukta śruti smṛti vādān āha tathā ca iti
translated: He states the scriptures and statements spoken earlier, which are favored by the supreme lord, regarding the excellence of knowledge, with and thus.

original: pūrvaṃ kalpādau sṛjati tasmai brahmaṇe prahiṇoti gamayati tasya buddhau vedānāvirbhāvayati
analyzed: pūrvam kalpa ādau sṛjati tasmai brahmaṇe prahiṇoti gamayati tasya buddhau vedān āvirbhāvayati
translated: In the beginning of the kalpa, he creates and sends to that Brahman, he conveys, he manifests the Vedas in his intellect.

original: yastaṃ devaṃ svātmākāraṃ mahāvākyotthabuddhau prakāśamānaṃ śaraṇaṃ paramamabhayasthānaṃ
analyzed: yaḥ tam devam sva ātma ākāram mahā vākya uttha buddhau prakāśamānam śaraṇam paramam abhaya sthānam
translated: He who takes refuge in that God, who appears in the intellect produced by the great statements in the form of one's own self, who is the highest place of fearlessness,

analyzed: niḥśreyasa rūpam aham prapadye iti arthaḥ
translated: who is of the nature of supreme bliss, I take refuge in him - this is the meaning.

original: na kevalamekasyaiva jñānātiśayaḥ kintu bahūnāṃ śākhādraṣṭṛṇāmiti viśvāsārthamāhasmarantīti /
analyzed: na kevalam ekasya eva jñāna atiśayaḥ kintu bahūnām śākhā draṣṭṛṇām iti viśvāsa artham āha smaranti iti
translated: Not only does one have superior knowledge, but many seers of the branches also have it - to inspire confidence, it is said 'they remember'.

analyzed: ṛgvedaḥ daśa maṇḍala avayavāḥ tatra bhavāḥ ṛcaḥ dāśatamyaḥ
translated: The Rig Veda has ten sections, the verses in it are the Dasatamyas.

original: vedāntare 'pi kāṇḍasūktamantrāṇāṃ draṣṭāro baudhāyanādibhiḥ smṛtā ityāhapratīti /
analyzed: veda antare pi kāṇḍa sūkta mantrāṇām draṣṭāraḥ baudhāyana ādibhiḥ smṛtāḥ iti āha prati iti
translated: In other Vedas also, the seers of the sections, hymns, and mantras are remembered by Baudhayana and others - thus it is said 'they remember'.

analyzed: kiñca mantrāṇām ṛṣi ādi jñāna āvaśyaka tva jñāpikā śrutiḥ mantra dṛś ṛṣīṇām jñāna atiśayam darśayati iti āha śrutiḥ api iti
translated: Moreover, the Shruti, which indicates the necessity of knowing the Rishis and other things of the mantras, shows the superior knowledge of the Rishis who saw the mantras - thus it is said 'the Shruti also'.

analyzed: ārṣeyaḥ ṛṣi yogaḥ
translated: 'Arsha' means connection with the Rishis.

analyzed: chandaḥ gāyatrī ādi
translated: 'Chanda' means the Gayatri meter, etc.

analyzed: daivatam agni ādi
translated: 'Daiva' means Agni and other deities.

analyzed: brāhmaṇam viniyogaḥ
translated: 'Brahmana' means application.

analyzed: etāni aviditāni yasmin mantre tena iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that the mantra in which these are unknown.

analyzed: sthāṇum sthāvaram
translated: 'Sthanu' means immobile.

analyzed: gartam narakam
translated: 'Garta' means hell.

original: tathāca jñānādhikaiḥ kalpāntaritaṃ vedaṃ smṛtvā vyavahārasya pravartitatvādvedasyānāditvamanapekṣatvaṃ cāvirūddhamiti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: tathā ca jñāna adhikaiḥ kalpa antaritam vedam smṛtvā vyavahārasya pravartita tvāt vedasya anādi tvam anapekṣa tvam ca avirūddham iti bhāvaḥ
translated: And thus, the idea is, the fact that the Veda, remembered by those who have superior knowledge, separated by the end of a Kalpa, and by which the usage is set in motion, is not contradicted by the fact that the Veda is beginningless and independent.

analyzed: adhunā samāna nāmarūpa tvam prapañcayati prāṇinām ca iti
translated: Now, he elaborates on the similarity of name and form, with the words 'and of living beings'.

analyzed: tatas kim tatra āha dṛṣṭā iti
translated: What then? There, he says 'in the seen'.

analyzed: aihika āmuṣmika viṣaya sukha rāga kṛta ṛmasya phalam paśu ādikam dṛṣṭa paśu ādi sadṛśyam iti yuktam
translated: It is proper that the fruit of action, such as cattle etc., created by attachment to pleasure in this world and the next, should be similar to the seen cattle etc.

analyzed: visadṛśe kāma abhāvena hetu abhāvāt
translated: Because there is no desire for the dissimilar, there is no cause.

analyzed: tathā dṛṣṭa duḥkha dveṣa kṛta adharma phalam dṛṣṭa sadṛśa duḥkham eva na sukham
translated: Similarly, the fruit of unrighteousness, created by hatred for seen suffering, is only suffering similar to the seen, not pleasure.

analyzed: kṛta hāni ādi doṣa āpatteḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that the fault of the omission of what has been done etc. would arise.

analyzed: tarkita arthe mānam āha smṛtiḥ ca iti
translated: In the inferred meaning, he states the proof with the words 'and the Smriti'.

analyzed: uttara sṛṣṭiḥ pūrva sṛṣṭi sajātīyā
translated: The subsequent creation is of the same kind as the previous creation.

analyzed: karma phala tvāt
translated: Because it is the fruit of action.

analyzed: pūrva sṛṣṭi vat iti anumānam caśabda arthaḥ
translated: The inference is that it is like the previous creation. This is the meaning of the word 'ca' (and).

analyzed: teṣām prāṇinām madhye tāni eva tad jātīyāni eva
translated: Among those living beings, those of the same kind, those very ones.

analyzed: tāni darśayan tad prāptau hetum āha hiṃsra iti
translated: Displaying them, he states the cause for attaining them with the words 'to the non-violent'.

analyzed: karmaṇi vihita niṣiddha tva ākāreṇa apūrvam
translated: In the action, the unseen is in the form of being enjoined or prohibited.

analyzed: kriyā tvena saṃskāram ca janayanti
translated: And they produce the impression by way of action.

analyzed: tatra apūrvāt phalam bhuṅkte
translated: There, one experiences the result from the antecedent.

analyzed: saṃskāra bhāvita tvāt punar tad jātīyāni karoti iti arthaḥ
translated: And because it is developed by the impression, it produces those of the same kind again. This is the meaning.

analyzed: saṃskāre liṅgam āha tasmāt iti
translated: He states the mark of the impression: therefore.

analyzed: saṃskāra vaśāt eva puṇyam pāpam vā rocate
translated: Merit or demerit is agreeable only by the power of the impression.

analyzed: atas bhiruci liṅgāt puṇya apuṇya saṃskāraḥ nu meyaḥ
translated: Therefore, from the mark of agreeableness, the impression of merit and demerit is to be inferred.

original: sa eva svabhāvaḥ prakṛtirvāsaneti ca gīyate /
analyzed: saḥ eva svabhāvaḥ prakṛtiḥ vāsanā iti ca gīyate
translated: That itself is called nature, innate tendency, and vāsanā.

original: evaṃ karmaṇāṃ sṛṣṭisādṛśyamuktvā svopādāne līnakāryasaṃskārarūpaśaktibalādapi sādṛśyamāhapralīyamānamiti /
analyzed: evam karmaṇām sṛṣṭi sādṛśyam uktvā sva upādāne līna kārya saṃskāra rūpa śakti balāt api sādṛśyam āha pralīyamānam iti
translated: Having thus stated the similarity of actions to creation, he states the similarity due to the power in the form of the impression of the dissolved effect in its own material cause: dissolving.

analyzed: itarathā niḥsaṃskāra pralaye jagat vaicitryasya ākasmika tvam syāt iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that otherwise, in the dissolution without impression, the diversity of the world would be accidental.

analyzed: nanu jagat vaicitrya kāriṇyaḥ nyāḥ śaktayaḥ kalpyantām
translated: But let other powers be postulated to bring about the diversity of the world.

analyzed: tatra aha na ca iti
translated: There, he says: not so.

original: avidyāyāṃ līnakāryātmakasaṃskārādanyāḥ śaktayo na kalpyāḥ manābhāvādrauravācca /
analyzed: avidyāyām līna kārya ātmaka saṃskārāt anyāḥ śaktayaḥ na kalpyāḥ manābhāvāt rauravāt ca
translated: Other powers than the impression in the form of the dissolved effect in ignorance are not to be postulated, due to the absence of mind and the heaviness of the matter.

analyzed: sva upādāne līna kārya rūpā śaktiḥ tu mahān nyagrodhaḥ tiṣṭhati śraddhatsva somya eti śruti siddhā
translated: But the power in the form of the dissolved effect in its own material cause is established by the Vedic texts: 'The great banyan tree stands', 'Have faith, my dear'

original: ato 'vidyātatkāryādanyāḥ śaktayo na santi ātmāvidyaiva tacchaktiriti siddhānta ityarthaḥ /
analyzed: atas vidyā tatkāryāt anyāḥ śaktayaḥ na santi ātma avidyā eva tad śaktiḥ iti siddhāntaḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: Therefore, the conclusion is that there are no other powers apart from ignorance and its effects, and the power of the self is just ignorance. This is the meaning.

analyzed: nimitteṣu api upādana stham kāryam eva avidyā ghaṭanayā śaktiḥ anyā vā iti anāgrahaḥ
translated: Even in the case of causes, there is no insistence on whether the effect that exists in the material cause is a power due to the arrangement of ignorance or something else.

analyzed: upādāne kārya saṃskāra siddheḥ phalam āha tatas ca iti
translated: Having established the impression of the effect in the material cause, he states the result: And from that...

original: yathā suptotthitasya pūrvacakṣurjātīyameva cakṣurjāyate tacca pūrvarūpajātīyameva rūpaṃ gṛhṇāti na rasādikaṃ /
analyzed: yathā supta utthitasya pūrva cakṣuḥ jātīyam eva cakṣuḥ jāyate tat ca pūrva rūpa jātīyam eva rūpam gṛhṇāti na rasa ādikam
translated: Just as for one who has risen from sleep, the eye that is born is of the same kind as the previous eye, and it perceives form that is of the same kind as the previous form, not taste etc.

original: evaṃ bhogya lokā bhogāśrayāḥ prāṇinikāyā bhogahetukarmāṇi saṃskārabalātpūrvalokāditulyānyeveti niyama ityarthaḥ /
analyzed: evam lokāḥ bhoga āśrayāḥ prāṇi nikāyāḥ bhoga hetu karmāṇi saṃskāra balāt pūrva loka ādi tulyāni eva iti niyamaḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: In the same way, the worlds to be enjoyed, the bodies of living beings that are the basis of enjoyment, and the actions that are the cause of enjoyment are regulated as if they were the same as the previous worlds and so on due to the force of impressions. This is the meaning of the rule.

analyzed: nikāyāḥ samūhāḥ
translated: Bodies are groups.

analyzed: dṛṣṭānta asiddhim āśaṅkyam āha na hi iti
translated: Fearing the non-establishment of the example, he says: For it is not so...

analyzed: yathā ṣaṣṭha indriyasya manasaḥ sādhāraṇa viṣayaḥ na asti
translated: Just as the sixth sense organ, the mind, does not have an uncommon object,

analyzed: suka ādeḥ sākṣi vedya tvāt
translated: because the happiness of the soul is known by the witness,

analyzed: tathā vyavahāra anyathātvam asat iti arthaḥ
translated: in the same way, the difference in usage is non-existent. This is the meaning.

analyzed: ṣaṣṭham indriyam tad viṣayaḥ ca āsan iti vā arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that the sixth sense organ and its object do not exist.

analyzed: ukta artham saṃkṣipati atas ca iti
translated: He summarizes the stated meaning with And from that...

analyzed: vyavahāra sāmyāt saṃbhavāt ca vyavahriyamāṇāḥ vyaktayaḥ samānāḥ eva iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that the manifest individual things that are spoken of are all the same, because they are similar in usage and because they are possible.

analyzed: sūtre yojayati samāna ityādinā
translated: He connects it with the sutra with the words same and so on.

original: bhāvidṛṣṭyā yajamāno 'gniḥ annādo 'ragnirahaṃ syāmiti kāmayitvā kṛttikānakṣatrābhimānidevāyāgnaye aṣṭasu kapāleṣu pacanīyaṃ havirniruptavānityarthaḥ
analyzed: bhāvi dṛṣṭyā yajamānaḥ gniḥ anna ādaḥ agniḥ aham syām iti kāmayitvā kṛttikā nakṣatra abhimāni devāya agnaye aṣṭasu kapāleṣu pacanīyam haviḥ niruptavān iti arthaḥ
translated: With the view of the future, the sacrificer is Agni. Having desired to be the eater of food, Agni, he, thinking I shall be Agni, the eater of food, offered the oblation to be cooked on eight potsherds to Agni, who is identified with the god who presides over the Krittika constellation.

analyzed: nakṣatra vyakti vahu tvāt bahuvacanam
translated: The plural is used because there are many individual stars.

original: jhrnanu yajamāno 'gnirbhāvī uddeśyāgninā samānanāmarūpaḥ kalpāntare bhavati /
analyzed: yajamānaḥ gniḥ bhāvī uddeśya agninā samāna nāma rūpaḥ kalpa antare bhavati

analyzed: jagat hetutva jīva aikyābhyām brahma iti arthaḥ

analyzed: jīva ukteḥ anya artha tvam upasaṃharati tasmāt iti
